tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is for the director of music to use in worship"
This may refer to a style of music.
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.

tn.ref: I will give thanks to Yahweh with my whole heart
tn.text: Since this song is addressed to Yahweh, Yahweh can be referred to as "you." AT: " Yahweh, I will give thanks to you with all my heart" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
The noun "deeds" can be expressed with the verb "do." AT: "all the marvelous things you do" or "all the marvelous things you have done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: I will sing praise to your name
tn.text: Here God's name represents God. AT: "I will sing praise to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"retreat" or "flee in fear"

tn.ref: you sit on your throne, a righteous judge
tn.text: Kings had authority to judge people, and they would sit on their throne when they judged. David speaks as if God were an earthly king.  AT: "you judge like a king who sits on his throne, and you are righteous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: you have blotted out their name forever and ever
tn.text: Causing people to be forgotten is spoken of as blotting out their name.  AT: "you have caused them to be forgotten as if their name was blotted out" or "no one will ever remember them again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"erased"
The enemy is spoken of as if it were a city full of broken down buildings. AT: "Our enemies were destroyed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"when you destroyed their cities"

tn.ref: All remembrance of them has perished
tn.text: Remembrance is spoken of as if it were a living being that could die. AT: "All remembrance of them has stopped" or "There is no longer any remembrance of them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: All remembrance of them has perished
tn.text: Remembrance can be expressed with the verb "remember." AT: "No one remembers them at all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"Remain" probably represents sitting on the throne as king. AT: "Yahweh sits on his throne forever" or "Yahweh rules forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: he has established his throne for justice
tn.text: The phrase "his throne" represents God's rule. Possible meanings are 1) "He rules in order to judge people" or "He rules over people justly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: He will judge the world with righteousness ... he will execute judgment for the nations with fairness
tn.text: These two clauses express the same meaning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: He will judge the world with righteousness
tn.text: Here "the world" refers to all the people in the world. AT: "He will judge all the people of the world righteously" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Yahweh also will be a stronghold for the oppressed
tn.text: God is spoken of as if he were a place that people could go to for safety. AT: "Yahweh will also protect the oppressed" or "Yahweh will also provide safety for those who are oppressed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"refuge" or "shelter"
Here the words "your name" represent God. AT: "Those who know you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"do not forsake" or "do not leave"
"who lives in Jerusalem"
Here "the nations" represent all of the people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: For the God who avenges bloodshed remembers
tn.text: What he remembers can be stated clearly. AT: "For the God who avenges bloodshed remembers those who were killed" or "For God remembers those who were killed and he punishes the killers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: he does not forget the cry
tn.text: "He does not ignore the cry"

tn.ref: see how I am oppressed by those who hate me
tn.text: This can be expressed in active form. AT: "see how those who hate me oppress me" or "see how badly my enemies treat me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: you who can snatch me from the gates of death
tn.text: Death is spoken of as if it were a city that had gates through which people enter it. If someone is near the gates of death, it means that he will die soon. Keeping someone from dying is spoken of as taking him away from the gates of that city. AT: "you who can rescue me from death" or "you who can keep me from dying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The nations have sunk down into the pit that they made
tn.text: People dig pits in order to catch animals that fall into them. Here digging a pit represents making plans to destroy people. AT: "The nations are like people who dig a pit for others and then fall into it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: their feet are caught in the net that they hid
tn.text: People hide nets in order to catch animals that get caught in them. Here hiding a net represents making plans to destroy people. AT: "they are like people who hide a net and get trapped in it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"trapped" or "caught." This represents being destroyed. AT: "destroyed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"rejected"

tn.ref: the destiny of all the nations that forget God
tn.text: "where all the nations that forget God will be"

tn.ref: For the needy will not always be forgotten
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will not always forget the needy" or "God will remember the needy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: nor will the hopes of the oppressed be forever dashed
tn.text: Hopes are spoken of as if they were objects that could be broken or destroyed. Hopes being destroyed represents the things that people hope for never happening. AT: "and the oppressed will not hope forever without results" or "and someday what the oppressed hope for will happen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Getting up represents starting to do something. AT: "Do something" or "Take action" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"people"
Here judging represents punishing. AT: "be punished" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here sight represents presence. AT: "in your presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: may the nations be judged in your sight
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "judge the nations in your presence" or "take the nations into your presence and punish them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
